    0. Creating a cubble from data in the wild

    0-create-cubble-from-wild.Rmd

    This article shows you how to create a cubble from data in the wild through an example of querying climate data from National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). Here I use a workflow involving row-wise data frame making it easy to organise and turn data into a cubble. This involves first create a row-wise tibble with one row per station, and then query the climate data as a nested list for each station.

    Find target stations

    Suppose we want to find a few climate stations close to Melbourne and Sydney, here we create a reference list with the longitude and latitude of both cities:

    (latlon_ref <- tibble::tibble(id = c("sydney", "melbourne"),
                         lat = c(-33.8675, -37.8136),
                         long = c(151.2070, 144.9631)))
#> # A tibble: 2 × 3
#>   id          lat  long
#>   <chr>     <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1 sydney    -33.9  151.
#> 2 melbourne -37.8  145.

    Usually, you also need a master list with all the candidate stations to choose from. Here we use the stations saved in the built-in data, aus_climate.

    (cand <- aus_climate %>% 
   as_tibble() %>% 
   select(id, lat, long, elev, name, wmo_id))
#> # A tibble: 85 × 6
#>    id            lat  long  elev name                   wmo_id
#>    <chr>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>                   <dbl>
#>  1 ASN00009021 -31.9  116.  15.4 perth airport           94610
#>  2 ASN00010311 -31.9  117. 179   york                    94623
#>  3 ASN00010614 -32.9  117. 338   narrogin                94627
#>  4 ASN00014015 -12.4  131.  30.4 darwin airport          94120
#>  5 ASN00015131 -17.6  134. 220   elliott                 94236
#>  6 ASN00016065 -30.4  137.  76   andamooka               95660
#>  7 ASN00023034 -35.0  139.   2   adelaide airport        94672
#>  8 ASN00023373 -34.5  139. 275   nuriootpa viticultural  94681
#>  9 ASN00024024 -34.4  141.  30.1 loxton research centre  94682
#> 10 ASN00024048 -34.2  141.  31.5 renmark aero            95687
#> # … with 75 more rows

    Sphereical distance between pair of stations can be calculated via rnoaa::meteo_spherical_distance(). We write a small wrapper function here to find the 5 closest stations in each city:

    calc_dist <- function(df_ref, df, n = 5){
  long_ref <- df_ref$long
  lat_ref <- df_ref$lat
  
  df %>% 
    mutate(long_ref = long_ref,
           lat_ref=  lat_ref,
           dist = rnoaa::meteo_spherical_distance(lat, long,lat_ref, long_ref)) %>% 
    slice_min(dist, n = n) %>% 
    mutate(city = df_ref$id) %>% 
    select(-long_ref, -lat_ref)
}

(stations <- do.call("rbind", purrr::map(1:nrow(latlon_ref), 
                             ~calc_dist(latlon_ref[.x, ], cand))))
#> # A tibble: 10 × 8
#>    id            lat  long  elev name                      wmo_id  dist city    
#>    <chr>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>                      <dbl> <dbl> <chr>   
#>  1 ASN00066037 -33.9  151.   6   sydney airport amo         94767  9.32 sydney  
#>  2 ASN00066194 -33.9  151.   3   canterbury racecourse aws  94766  9.63 sydney  
#>  3 ASN00066124 -33.8  151.  55   parramatta north (masons…  94764 19.4  sydney  
#>  4 ASN00066137 -33.9  151.   6.5 bankstown airport aws      94765 21.1  sydney  
#>  5 ASN00068192 -34.0  151.  73.9 camden airport aws         94755 51.4  sydney  
#>  6 ASN00086038 -37.7  145.  78.4 essendon airport           95866 10.8  melbour…
#>  7 ASN00086282 -37.7  145. 113.  melbourne airport          94866 20.1  melbour…
#>  8 ASN00086077 -38.0  145.  12.1 moorabbin airport          94870 21.9  melbour…
#>  9 ASN00088162 -37.4  145. 528.  wallan (kilmore gap)       94860 48.1  melbour…
#> 10 ASN00087113 -38.0  144.  10.6 avalon airport             94854 48.8  melbour…

    Query weather data

    The weather station data can be queried by rnoaa::meteo_pull_monitors() with the date range and variable supplied. Here the use of row-wise operation nests the queried climate data into a ts column. The nested data is then ready to be turned into a cubble with

    • id as the key to identify each station,
    • date as the index to identify time, and
    • coords to identify the spatial coordinates of each station.
    sydmel_climate <- stations %>% 
  rowwise() %>% 
  mutate(ts = list(meteo_pull_monitors(id, 
                                       date_min = "2020-01-01", 
                                       date_max = "2020-12-31",
                                       var = c("PRCP", "TMAX", "TMIN")) %>% 
                     select(-id))) %>% 
  as_cubble(key = id, index = date, coords = c(long, lat))
    #> # Cubble: id-wise: nested form
#> # Key:    id [10]
#>    id            lat  long  elev name             wmo_id  dist city   ts        
#>    <chr>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>             <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  <list>    
#>  1 ASN00066037 -33.9  151.   6   sydney airport …  94767  9.32 sydney <tibble […
#>  2 ASN00066194 -33.9  151.   3   canterbury race…  94766  9.63 sydney <tibble […
#>  3 ASN00066124 -33.8  151.  55   parramatta nort…  94764 19.4  sydney <tibble […
#>  4 ASN00066137 -33.9  151.   6.5 bankstown airpo…  94765 21.1  sydney <tibble […
#>  5 ASN00068192 -34.0  151.  73.9 camden airport …  94755 51.4  sydney <tibble […
#>  6 ASN00086038 -37.7  145.  78.4 essendon airport  95866 10.8  melbo… <tibble […
#>  7 ASN00086282 -37.7  145. 113.  melbourne airpo…  94866 20.1  melbo… <tibble […
#>  8 ASN00086077 -38.0  145.  12.1 moorabbin airpo…  94870 21.9  melbo… <tibble […
#>  9 ASN00088162 -37.4  145. 528.  wallan (kilmore…  94860 48.1  melbo… <tibble […
#> 10 ASN00087113 -38.0  144.  10.6 avalon airport    94854 48.8  melbo… <tibble […
